name: presumable
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
able to be presumed (= believed likely to be true): Government regulations prohibited the merger from taking place due to presumable violations of anti-trust laws. It is presumable that important changes are already underway.
More examplesFewer examplesSince it is presumed that juries are best judges of facts, it is presumable that the courts are the best judges of the law. Critics tend to stress the works' formal perfection, but also justify his presumable lack of success as a poet.Presumable multilingualism often remains unrecognized, and the children of immigrants are represented as lacking in language skills.
